title: Eating terumah before sunset
vignette: A man immerses in the mikveh for purity but the sun has not yet set. He is hungry for the priestly terumah meal awaiting him.

options.text: Wait until after sunset to eat.
Eat immediately since immersion is complete.

title: Handling sacrificial meat
vignette: After immersion, a temple worker wants to move consecrated meat to a cooler place though nightfall has not yet come.

options.text: Avoid touching it until sunset.
Move it quickly to prevent spoilage.

title: Entering the Temple courtyard
vignette: A person who immersed earlier has an urgent message for a priest inside the courtyard.

options.text: He waits outside until sunset.
He may enter briefly for the essential errand.

title: Touching wine tithes
vignette: Barrels of terumah wine leaked during the day. The tevul yom wants to rescue what remains before it spoils.

options.text: He should direct others but not touch it.
Saving the wine takes priority; he may handle it.

title: Borrowed garments
vignette: Needing clean clothes, the tevul yom asks to borrow a friend’s garments before nightfall.

options.text: Wait until sunset so as not to transmit impurity.
Borrow now and return them once pure.

title: Starting a festive meal
vignette: A family gathers for a celebration in the afternoon. One member is a tevul yom and wonders if he may eat with them.

options.text: Wait until evening to join the meal.
Participate now in non-sacred foods.

title: Helping with Temple service
vignette: The sanctuary is short-staffed just before sunset. A tevul yom volunteer offers assistance with preparations.

options.text: Decline his help until he becomes fully pure.
Allow him to assist in tasks that don’t involve sacred items.

title: Re-immersion due to doubt
vignette: Unsure whether his earlier immersion was valid, a tevul yom considers immersing again before evening.

options.text: Better to immerse again to remove doubt.
Trust the original immersion and wait for sunset.

title: Delivering holy bread
vignette: A tevul yom must bring loaves of showbread to the Temple but it is still day.

options.text: Ask someone else to deliver them.
Carry them himself to avoid delay.

title: Sharing a ride on sacred utensils
vignette: Donkeys carrying temple vessels pass by. The tevul yom wants a lift to town.

options.text: He should not ride with the holy items before sunset.
It is permitted since he won’t touch them.

title: Bringing gifts to a mourner
vignette: A friend sits shiva and expects consolation gifts. The tevul yom wonders if he may deliver them now.

options.text: Wait until evening to avoid any impurity concern.
Deliver the gifts immediately to comfort the mourner.

title: Handling common produce
vignette: A market vendor wants help arranging fruits for sale. A tevul yom customer offers assistance.

options.text: He may help since the produce is unconsecrated.
He should refrain until fully pure.

title: Returning pledged items
vignette: A debtor must return collateral to its owner before nightfall. The messenger is currently a tevul yom.

options.text: Send someone else to return it.
Return it himself despite partial impurity.

title: Attending a wedding feast
vignette: A relative’s wedding begins shortly before sunset. May the tevul yom enter the hall and celebrate?

options.text: He may attend but avoid touching others’ food.
Wait outside until evening before joining.

title: Questionable sunset
vignette: Clouds obscure the horizon and it’s uncertain if night has fallen. The tevul yom is eager to eat terumah.

options.text: Wait until darkness is clear.
Assume it’s night and begin his meal.
